results.title: Indian Ocean
results.brief_description: Describes the growth of the Empire round the Indian Ocean. Barred from the East Indies, the British established themselves on the mainland of India, where they were followed by the French. The rivalry of these two great nations led to their entry into the politics of India, and intense trading, political and naval rivalry until the fall of Napoleon in 1815.

results.title: Indian festival
results.brief_description: A survey of the festivals of India, seasonal and religious, which take place in large and small communities throughout the land and during all months of the year. Vast numbers of people take part in processions, rituals, re-creations of events, songs and dances to request the assistance of various gods or to thank them for their help during the past year. Brief glimpses of some art forms and decorations associated with the ceremonies are shown.

results.title: Indian fantasy
results.brief_description: Intended as one episode in a full length animated and colour feature cartoon of Jules Verne’s “Round the World in Eighty Days”, this sequence shows the beginning and end of the journey and the adventures of Phileas Fogg and his servant in India. The film was commenced in 1938 but was not completed.

results.title: Indian eyes on the future
results.brief_description: Shows the progress India is making towards an indpendent future. Highly competent scientists and technologists argue that India must make herself technologically independent quickly, and to do this she must invest heavily in fundamental research, even though many millions of her people still live in squalor. Shows the Plutonium factory near Bombay, the new steel town of Dargapur, and the first atomic power station under construction at Taraput. Presents the enormous problem of education facing India.

results.title: The Indian elephant
results.brief_description: Catching and training a young work elephant. The life of the herd in the jungle; digging a pit trap over a forest path; moving the trapped elephant; the elephant overcomes his fear and submits to training; finally it is seen loading logs on to railway trucks.

results.title: Indian art through the ages
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The camera explores exhibits at a display of fine arts in New Delhi, India to reveal the artistic achievements of past civilizations. Shows terracotta models which decorated the city of Mohenjodaro, 4500 years ago; includes specimens of Maurya, Kushan, Gupta and Chola art.

results.title: Indo-Australia cricket tests, 1964
results.brief_description: A survey of the tour of India by the Australian Test Team in 1964. Shows highlights of the matches played in various cities and the personalities associated with the tour. A very successful series of matches which drew large and enthusiastic crowds.

results.title: India welcomes the Queen, 1961
results.creator_credit: British Movietone News and Commonwealth Relations Office
results.brief_description: H.M. the Queen’s tour of India, 1961. Episodes include the Royal arrival at Delhi, splendours of a Durbar at Jaipur, the spectacular Republic Day parade in Delhi, and visits to the Taj Mahal, Durgapur steelworks, the botanical gardens at Bangalore, and the cities of Calcutta, Madras, and the Holy city of Benares.

results.title: The India trip
results.creator_credit: Bill Davies, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Pondicherry, an ancient city near the Southern tip of India, was for several centuries an outpost of France. Now the French influence has faded but another, stranger, colony is growing on its outskirts - Auroville, a community of Europeans and North Americans who have come to live the contemplative life. They are devotees of Sri Aurobindo, a Bengali poet and mystic, and their guru is a ninety-four-year-old woman from France. This spiritual mecca is described in the film by Albert Jordan, a professor from Concordia University, Montreal, who, in 1971, with his family, spent a year there.
